Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2019 Midwest Programming Languages Summit (MWPLS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will support student travel to the Midwest Programming Languages Summit, to be held at Purdue University in September 2019. This research workshop will serve as a valuable forum for researchers and students to share in-progress research ideas and receive timely feedback to influence subsequent work. This will be particularly valuable because of the high concentration of programming languages researchers in the Midwest, and because it will provide graduate student researchers opportunities to network and further develop their research and presentation skills.

The funds from this award will help support U.S. based students, focusing on graduate students at an advanced stage in their program and students who would otherwise not be able to attend this workshop. The impacts include training the next generation of researchers in this important research area. Higher priority will be assigned to students giving presentations and a strong emphasis will be put on supporting students from underrepresented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 Midwest PL Summit (MWPLS) was held at Purdue University on September 24, 2019. MWPLS is a symposium that brings together programming language researchers--faculty, researchers, students, and industry participants--from around the Midwest to share work in progress and initiate collaborations. This was the fifth edition of MWPLS. Previous editions were held at Purdue (2016), the University of Chicago (2017), Indiana University (2018), and the University of Wisconsin (2019).

MWPLS 2019 was attended by approximately 200 people, including attendees from a dozen universities and a half dozen companies. The symposium featured 25 talks, selected from approximately 45 submissions, a poster session, and a social event in the evening.

This project provided travel support for students from outside Purdue to travel to the event and stay near the venue. The funds were able to provide hotel accommodations for 32 students (with double occupancy) from the following universities: Indiana University, University of Chicago, UIUC, University of Michigan, Ohio State University, University of Kansas, University of Wisconsin and University of Iowa. This was sufficient to provide accommodations to all students who requested them. The funds were also used to defray travel costs for these students, pro-rated by how far they had to travel. On average, each student who received travel cost reimbursement received $80 (not counting hotel accommodations).
